title: Ticket #659: Add a log reader file descriptor throttle to DAGMan
description:
Note: I was manually running a large DAG test with a 20,000 x 5 node DAG, and this failed because of running out of file descriptors when it went into recovery mode.

What I have in mind is that there would be some way to tell the lazy log file code to only have n file descriptors open at any given time, and it would open and close files as necessary to maintain that. One simple (but non-optimal) way to reduce the FD use in a DAG with lots of parallel nodes would be to just open and close each log file each time we look at it.
remarks:
2009-Aug-10 13:35:32 by matt:
It's better to have a limit. Open and close on each event/read is a performance killer. It is currently making the EVENT_LOG quite slow.

Can the immediate problem of the large dag test be changed to use fewer log files?

2009-Aug-10 13:59:57 by wenger:
The problem is not really that I got the large DAG test to fail -- the problem is that a real user might conceivable generate a DAG that would require a similar number of log files to be read.

I don't think this is real urgent, because we're at least no worse off with the new "lazy log file" code than with the old code. But if a user has a very "wide" DAG, it's still possible for DAGMan to really have a lot of log files open at the same time.

2012-Jan-31 12:07:06 by bbockelm:
You can see how we handle it here:

https://github.com/mattf/condor_job_queue_publisher

The basic idea is to use inotify as a "hint" that data is available, and drastically reduce the polling interval. In the end, you still must poll the files because inotify is not infallible. It's just pretty dang good.

In terms of the number of file descriptors, inotify is going to use one file descriptor per instance, but you have to manage something else called "watch descriptors". These still are going to take up memory (kernel and application side), but aren't counted against your fd limit.

Unfortunately, I can't offer any insights into the equivalent entities in Windows.
